Award.AwardTitle: Sequence Requirements for Protein-Based Genetic Elements

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the most fundamental questions in biology is how organisms store and pass on genetic information. Research in the growing field of epigenetics has demonstrated that genetic information is not always encoded within an organism's DNA sequence. The discovery of yeast prions showed that changes in protein structure can be used to transmit genetic information. The formation of yeast prions involves the conversion of soluble proteins into an insoluble amyloid form. The amyloid form can be stably passed from mother to daughter cell, allowing the encoded epigenetic information to be passed on as a protein-based genetic element. This project examines the hypothesis that such structural conversions represent a common epigenetic mechanism of cellular regulation and inheritance in eukaryotes. A combination of in vitro and in vivo assays will be employed to define the sequence features that allow certain proteins to undergo prion-like structural conversions. This information will then be used to identify novel proteins whose activities are regulated by prion-like structural conversions. Taken together, these studies will advance our understanding of the role of such structural conversions in eukaryotic regulation and inheritance.

Broader Impacts: In addition to the intellectual merit, this project has three major areas of broader impact. First, much of the research will be conducted in the context of a novel laboratory course, which is designed to be a hybrid of independent research and traditional laboratory classes. This course will allow students to generate new, publishable research, but in a sufficiently structured setting to allow for training of a large number of students. The course is designed to offer a diverse interdisciplinary training experience in biochemistry, molecular biology, genetics and bioinformatics. Second, as yeast are safe and inexpensive to work with, they provide an excellent system for teaching basic concepts of biochemistry and genetics to younger ages. Therefore, aspects of the research will be used in an elementary school outreach project called "Biochemistry is Elementary." This project introduces students to the scientific process and to basic concepts in biochemistry using exciting, hands-on activities. Finally, this work involves the development of novel technologies for the quantitative monitoring of prion dynamics, which will have applications for future research into regulatory prions and for industrial applications of amyloid fibrils.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research in the growing field of epigenetics has demonstrated that genetic information is not always encoded within the primary DNA (or RNA) sequence of an organism’s genome.  The discovery of yeast prions showed that changes in protein structure can be used to transmit genetic information.  Yeast prion formation involves the conversion of soluble proteins into an insoluble amyloid form.  The amyloid form can be stably passed from mother to daughter cell, allowing the encoded epigenetic information to be passed on as a protein-based genetic element.  Evidence from a variety of systems has demonstrated that such structural conversions can be used to regulate the activity of certain proteins.  Each of the yeast prion proteins contains a glutamine/asparagine (Q/N) rich domain that drives amyloid formation.  Such domains are over-represented in eukaryotic genomes, suggesting that prion-like structural conversions may represent a commonly used, but currently underappreciated, mechanism of biological regulation.  However, this theory has been difficult to test; until recently, the field has had very little success developing algorithms to predict whether a given Q/N-rich domain will be prone to amyloid fibril formation.  Therefore, the primary goal of this project was to more rigorously define the amino acid sequence requirements for prion-like activity.

 

We made important progress towards this goal during the project. We developed PAPA, an online prediction algorithm designed predict the prion activity of Q/N-rich proteins.  We showed that PAPA was effective at discriminating between Q/N-rich proteins with and without prion activity. Additionally, PAPA was sufficient to design mutation to modulate the prion activity of known prion domains; to design new prion domains de novo; and to design mutation to create prion-like activity in non-prion Q/N-rich domains. We demonstrated that different amino acid sequence features drive the formation and propagation of prions, and developed a quantitative mutagenesis strategy to separately define these requirements. Finally, we used PAPA to search various genomes to identify potential prion domains, and tested approximately 50 of these in various assays for aggregation and prion activity.

 

In addition to this intellectual merit, the project had two major areas of broader impact.  First, much of the research was conducted by undergraduates, either in the context of a novel laboratory course or as independent study. This provided students with experience in scientific research, and resulted in five separate papers at least one undergraduate co-author.  Second, as yeast are safe and inexpensive to work with, they provide an excellent system teaching basic concepts of biochemistry and genetics to younger ages.  Therefore, aspects of the proposed research were used in an elementary school outreach project called “Biochemistry is Elementary.”  This program introduces students to the scientific process and to basic concepts in biochemistry and genetics using exciting, hands-on activities. During the course of the project, over 300 5th grade students participated in the “Biochemistry is Elementary” program.
